question.title: Switch statement in constructor
question.body:
I want to create a Potion class with different effects, and my initial approach was to use a switch statement in the constructor to determine the potion's properties. However, this doesn't work because the Potion class inherits from a parent class, Item, which requires values like name and description. Since I need to call super in the constructor to pass these values, I'm struggling to find a way to implement the effect logic properly.

package Items;

public class Potion extends Item {
    private int effect;
    private int amount;


    public Potion(int effect, int amount) {

        switch(effect) {
            case 0 -> super("Potion of regeneration", "", "Potion");
            case 1 -> super("Potion of attack power", "", "Potion");
        }

        this.effect = effect;
        this.amount = amount;
    }
}

In the constructor super isn't a top level statement which it has to be. Is there any way I can work around this?

answers.body:
In current JDK the call to super must be first line, so you can adjust with these approaches:

public Potion(int effect, int amount) {
    super(effect==0 ? "Potion of regeneration": "Potion of attack power", "", "Potion");
    this.effect = effect;
    this.amount = amount;
}

If your case might be extended, use a helper function:

private static String potion(int effect) {
    return switch(effect) {
        case 0 -> "Potion of regeneration";
        case 1 -> "Potion of attack power";
        // Other values here ...
        default -> throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unexpected value: "+effect);
    };
}
public Potion(int effect, int amount) {
    super(potion(effect), "", "Potion");

    this.effect = effect;
    this.amount = amount;
}

JDK25 should provide flexible constructor bodies as part of JEP-513 which allow inline prologue before super:

public Potion(int effect, int amount) {
    String pe = switch(effect) {
        case 0 -> "Potion of regeneration";
        case 1 -> "Potion of attack power";
        // Other values here ...
        default -> throw new IllegalArgumentException("Unexpected value: "+effect);
    };
    super(pe, "", "Potion");
}

... which is a bit tidier than simply inserting the switch where pe is.

I can think of a couple of ways to do this:

  1. Call super with argument expression that computes the required value; e.g.

     super(effect == 0 ? "Potion of regeneration" : "Potion of attack power", 
       "", "Potion");

    or

     super(POTION_NAMES[effect], "", "Potion");

    Alternatively, declare and call a static method to generate lookup the required value; e.g.

     super(computePotionName(effect), "", "Potion");

  2. In Java 17 and later use a switch expression in the super call.

  3. In Java 22 and later, use the new preview language feature specified by JEP 447 that allows statements before the super call.

    Note: there are followup versions as JEPs 482, 492, 513, though the JEP documents imply that there have been "no changes" since 482. This language feature is due to become a non-preview feature in Java 25.

question_comments.body: Sounds like a job for subclasses: abstract class Potion {...} class RegeneratonPotion extends Potion {...} class AttackPotion extends Potion {...}?

You can use super(effect==0 ? "Potion of regeneration": "Potion of attack power", "", "Potion"), or put the switch in a function super(potion(effect), "", "Potion"). JDK25 should allow flexible constructor body to compute potion effect before calling super(pe,...)
